importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the meeting in London where the IMO voted to postpone the Net Zero Framework adoption, following Trump's threat of sanctions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The framework was delayed until late next year, meaning full implementation of the emissions regulation for shipping is now expected to occur after at least 12 months of postponement.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to threats from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the carbon tax on shipping emissions.
The NZF would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, charging ships $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions.
The framework aims to cut shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050.
Countries supporting the plan included China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain, and others; opposition came from Russia and Saudi Arabia.
Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, voted to postpone adoption.
The decision was criticized as a missed opportunity by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres and the International Chamber of Shipping.
Vanuatu's climate minister Ralph Regenvanu called the delay 'unacceptable' given the urgency of climate change.
Climate change is already affecting shipping through altered ocean currents and more frequent storms.

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries supporting a global carbon tax on shipping emissions, leading the International Maritime Organization (IMO) to postpone the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months. The NZF, which would have introduced a $380 per metric tonne carbon pricing system for ships, was previously approved in April but delayed due to political pressure from the United States. Despite support from major economies like China, the EU, and Britain, opposition from Russia and Saudi Arabia, along with shifts from Argentina and Singapore, contributed to the vote. The decision was condemned by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres and the International Chamber of Shipping as a missed opportunity to advance climate action in shipping, which is already being impacted by extreme weather and changing ocean conditions. The delay undermines progress toward the IMO’s goal of reducing shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and achieving net zero by 2050.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
